awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  LBRC LED Lighting Control
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is targeted at developing a new light-emitting diode (LED) lighting control system called Light Bursts with RF Control. Existing lighting control systems are typically burdened by the need for centralized control system that requires significant upfront costs and commissioning. By employing light burst communication between the LED fixtures and work-space sensors, the Light Bursts with RF Control system moves the point of lighting control from a commissioned system, which often requires a central processor, to point-of-use wireless sensors that do not require commissioning. Light Bursts with RF Control employs work-space sensors that monitor the light bursts from the fixtures, provides direct feedback to the fixtures via wireless communication, is intuitive to use, and allows the lighting to be readily adjusted to the space and occupant needs in real-time.  It is anticipated that this research will result in an intuitive low cost control system that does not require upfront commissioning.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is anticipated to significantly lower installation costs and improve usability. The adoption of energy efficient LED lighting has been slow and is hindered by the need to install and commission costly central processing systems. LED penetration into indoor troffers, which in 2010 represented 957 million unique commercially available units, is less than a 0.1%. By removing and reducing the conventional barriers to energy efficient lighting and control, Light Bursts with RF Control will improve the adoption of LED lighting and enable significant energy savings associated with lighting. By intelligently employing wireless technology with direct correlation of light contribution from individual light fixtures, Light Bursts with RF Control is expected to enable reductions in lighting energy usage by more than 20%-60%.

por.por_cntn:
Light burst with radio frequency control (LBRC) is a new technology that takes advantage of the unique ability of LEDs to rapidly switch their on/off illumination states to create a novel lighting control architecture that eliminates the commissioning previously associated with efficient lighting architectures – the proposed LBRC architecture will lower cost and complexity of energy efficient lighting controls and is compatible with daylighting and personal workspace (occupant) illumination control. The Phase I research created hardware and software to create and detect rapid changes in the illumination of more than one LED fixture and established a self-commissioning LED lighting architecture among the fixtures.

 

The Phase I LBRC is based on imperceptible LED modulation using low-cost photo detectors and wireless transceivers. The research was guided by three technical objectives: (1) creating a faster LED modulation circuit, (2) creating a circuit to detect the faster LED modulation, and (3) fabricating and demonstrating a small-scale prototype that demonstrates the ability for a sensor to control more than one LED fixture to achieve lighting control without commissioning. The technical objectives and objectives for each of the technical tasks were successfully completed. First, a prototype LED modulation circuit was developed and able to generate repeatable 10 µs “negative” optical pulses.  Evaluations of sequences of optical pulses constructed to form a 16-bit network address were not perceptible.  Second, development of the low-cost LED demodulation detection circuit was more challenging because the optical sampling rate requires a significant portion of the available CPU capacity common in the low-cost architecture required to meet the cost criteria of the LED industry.  A prototype demodulation detection circuit successfully and reliably reconstructed 16-bit network addresses over ranges of total illumination from 5 to 15,000 lx, exceeding the planned range of illumination.  Finally, a prototype system of LED downlights automatically established a network relationship and successfully adjusted their LED illumination levels based on user requests while compensating for ambient illumination (daylighting) to save energy.  The success of the fundamental concepts of the LBRC architecture were verified using external light meters and by mathematically evaluating the raw illumination data generated by the detection circuit.
